original: Majjhima Nikāya 115
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Bahudhātukasutta
analyzed: bahu dhātuka sutta
translated: The Many Kinds of Elements

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Bhikkhus!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Yāni kānici, bhikkhave, bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
analyzed: yāni kānici bhikkhave bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ
translated: “Whatever fears arise, bhikkhus, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man;

original: ye keci upaddavā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
analyzed: ye keci upaddavāḥ uppajjanti sabbe te bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ
translated: whatever dangers arise, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man;

original: ye keci upasaggā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato.
analyzed: ye keci upasaggāḥ uppajjanti sabbe te bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ
translated: whatever calamities arise, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, naḷāgārā vā tiṇāgārā vā aggi mutto kūṭāgārānipi dahati ullittāvalittāni nivātāni phusitaggaḷāni pihitavātapānāni;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave naḷa āgārāḥ vā tiṇa āgārāḥ vā aggi muttaḥ kūṭāgārāni pi dahati ullitta avalittāni nivātāni phusita ggaḷāni pihita vāta pānāni
translated: Suppose a fire broke out in a reed-bed, and a man came with a basket of ashes: he would not be able to extinguish that fire. So it is with the fool: he is not able to extinguish the fire of passion that has arisen in himself.

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāni kānici bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;🔽ye keci upaddavā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato;
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave yāni kānici bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ  ye keci upaddavāḥ uppajjanti sabbe te bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ
translated: In the same way, whatever dangers arise, they all arise because of the foolish, not because of the wise.🔽Whatever calamities arise, they all arise because of the foolish, not because of the wise.

original: ye keci upasaggā uppajjanti sabbe te bālato uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato.
analyzed: ye keci upasaggāḥ uppajjanti sabbe te bālataḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ
translated: Whatever misfortunes arise, they all arise because of the foolish, not because of the wise.

original: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sappaṭibhayo bālo, appaṭibhayo paṇḍito;
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave sa paṭibhayaḥ bālaḥ appaṭibhayaḥ paṇḍitaḥ
translated: So, monks, the foolish are to be feared, but the wise are not to be feared.

original: saupaddavo bālo, anupaddavo paṇḍito;🔽saupasaggo bālo, anupasaggo paṇḍito.
analyzed: saupaddavaḥ bālaḥ anupaddavaḥ paṇḍito  sa upasaggaḥ bālaḥ an upasaggaḥ paṇḍito
translated: The foolish are to be feared, but the wise are not to be feared.🔽The foolish are to be feared, but the wise are not to be feared.

original: Natthi, bhikkhave, paṇḍitato bhayaṁ, natthi paṇḍitato upaddavo, natthi paṇḍitato upasaggo.
analyzed: natthi bhikkhave paṇḍitataḥ bhaya natthi paṇḍitataḥ upaddavaḥ natthi paṇḍitataḥ upasaggo
translated: There is no danger from the wise, no calamity from the wise, no misfortune from the wise.🔽Therefore, monks, you should train yourselves:

original: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘paṇḍitā bhavissāma vīmaṁsakā’ti—🔽evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabban”ti.
analyzed: tasmā ati ha bhikkhave paṇḍitāḥ bhavissāma vīmasakā ati  evam hi vaḥ bhikkhave sikkhitabbanti
translated: ‘We will be wise and discerning.’

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Ven. Ānanda said to the Blessed One,

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, paṇḍito bhikkhu ‘vīmaṁsako’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante paṇḍitaḥ bhikkhu vīmasakoti alavacanāya ati
translated: “To what extent, lord, is a monk wise and discerning, to the point of deserving to be called ‘wise and discerning’?”

original: “Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu dhātukusalo ca hoti, āyatanakusalo ca hoti, paṭiccasamuppādakusalo ca hoti, ṭhānāṭhānakusalo ca hoti—
analyzed: yatas kho ānanda bhikkhu dhātu kusalo ca hoti āyatana kusalo ca hoti paṭiccasamuppāda kusalo ca hoti ṭhāna aṭhāna kusalo ca hoti
translated: “When a monk is skilled in the elements, in the sense spheres, in dependent origination, and in what is possible and impossible,

original: ettāvatā kho, ānanda, paṇḍito bhikkhu ‘vīmaṁsako’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho ānanda paṇḍitaḥ bhikkhu vīmasakoti alavacanāya ati
translated: he is wise, and so can rightly be called a monk who investigates.”

original: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā pana bhante dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “But, Sir, how is a monk skilled in the elements?”

original: “Aṭṭhārasa kho imā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa kho imāḥ ānanda dhātuyaḥ
translated: “There are eighteen elements:

original: cakkhudhātu, rūpadhātu, cakkhuviññāṇadhātu;🔽sotadhātu, saddadhātu, sotaviññāṇadhātu;🔽ghānadhātu, gandhadhātu, ghānaviññāṇadhātu;
analyzed: cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu  sota dhātu sadda dhātu sota viññāṇa dhātu  ghāna dhātu gandha dhātu ghāna viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the eye element, the form element, the eye-consciousness element;🔽the ear element, the sound element, the ear-consciousness element;🔽the nose element, the smell element, the nose-consciousness element;

original: jivhādhātu, rasadhātu, jivhāviññāṇadhātu;
analyzed: jivhā dhātu rasa dhātu jivhā viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the tongue element, the taste element, the tongue-consciousness element;

original: kāyadhātu, phoṭṭhabbadhātu, kāyaviññāṇadhātu;
analyzed: kāya dhātu phoṭṭhabba dhātu kāya viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the body element, the touch element, the body-consciousness element;

original: manodhātu, dhammadhātu, manoviññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the mind element, the thought element, the mind-consciousness element.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: When a monk knows and sees

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: he is skilled in the elements, and so can rightly be called a monk who investigates.”

original: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: siyā pana bhante aññaḥ api pariyāyaḥ yathā dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “Could there be another way of describing a monk who is skilled in the elements?”

original: “Siyā, ānanda.
analyzed: siyā ānanda
translated: “There could, Ānanda.

original: Chayimā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: ānanda dhātuyo
translated: There are these six elements:

original: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu ākāsa dhātu viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda cha dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: When a monk knows and sees these six elements as they actually are,

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: then he is called a monk who is skilled in the elements.”

original: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: siyā pana bhante aññaḥ api pariyāyaḥ yathā dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “Could there be another way of describing a monk who is skilled in the elements?”

original: “Siyā, ānanda.
analyzed: siyā ānanda
translated: “There could, Ānanda.

original: Chayimā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: ānanda dhātuyo
translated: There are these six elements:

original: sukhadhātu, dukkhadhātu, somanassadhātu, domanassadhātu, upekkhādhātu, avijjādhātu.
analyzed: sukha dhātu dukkha dhātu somanassa dhātu domanassa dhātu upekkhā dhātu avijjā dhātu
translated: the element of pleasure, the element of pain, the element of joy, the element of grief, the element of equanimity, and the element of ignorance.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda cha dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: When a monk knows and sees these six elements as they actually are,

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: then he is called a monk who is skilled in the elements.”

original: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: siyā pana bhante aññaḥ api pariyāyaḥ yathā dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “Could there be another way of describing a monk who is skilled in the elements?”

original: “Siyā, ānanda.
analyzed: siyā ānanda
translated: “There could, Ānanda.

original: Chayimā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: ānanda dhātuyo
translated: There are these six elements:

original: kāmadhātu, nekkhammadhātu, byāpādadhātu, abyāpādadhātu, vihiṁsādhātu, avihiṁsādhātu.
analyzed: kāmadhātu nekkhammadhātu byāpāda dhātu a byāpāda dhātu vihisā dhātu a vihisā dhātu
translated: the element of the sensual sphere, the element of renunciation, the element of ill will, the element of non-ill will, the element of cruelty, and the element of non-cruelty.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, cha dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda cha dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: When a monk knows and sees these six elements as they actually are,

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: then he is called a monk who is skilled in the elements and deserves to be called a scholar of the Dhamma.”

original: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: siyā pana bhante aññaḥ api pariyāyaḥ yathā dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “Could there be another way of describing a monk who is skilled in the elements?”

original: “Siyā, ānanda.
analyzed: siyā ānanda
translated: “There could, Ānanda.

original: Tisso imā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: tissaḥ imāḥ ānanda dhātuyaḥ
translated: There are these three elements:

original: kāmadhātu, rūpadhātu, arūpadhātu.
analyzed: kāmadhātu rūpadhātu arūpadhātu
translated: the element of the sensual sphere, the element of the form sphere, and the element of the formless sphere.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, tisso dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda tissaḥ dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: When a monk knows and sees these three elements as they actually are,

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: then he is called a monk who is skilled in the elements and deserves to be called a scholar of the Dhamma.”

original: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo, yathā ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: siyā pana bhante aññaḥ api pariyāyaḥ yathā dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “Could there be another way of describing a monk who is skilled in the elements?”

original: “Siyā, ānanda.
analyzed: siyā ānanda
translated: “There could be, Ānanda.

original: Dve imā, ānanda, dhātuyo—
analyzed: dve imāḥ ānanda dhātuyaḥ
translated: There are these two properties:

original: saṅkhatādhātu, asaṅkhatādhātu.
analyzed: saṅkhatā dhātu a saṅkhatā dhātu
translated: the conditioned and the unconditioned.🔽When a monk knows and sees

original: Imā kho, ānanda, dve dhātuyo yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāḥ kho ānanda dve dhātuyaḥ yatas jānāti passati
translated: these two properties as they actually are,

original: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, ‘dhātukusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho ānanda dhātu kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: he is said to be a monk who is skilled in the properties.”

original: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, ‘āyatanakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā pana bhante āyatana kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “But, Sir, in what way is a monk skilled in the sense fields?”

original: “Cha kho panimāni, ānanda, ajjhattikabāhirāni āyatanāni—
analyzed: cha kho panimāni ānanda ajjhattika bāhirāni āyatanāni
translated: “There are these six internal and external sense fields:

original: cakkhu ceva rūpā ca sotañca saddā ca ghānañca gandhā ca jivhā ca rasā ca kāyo ca phoṭṭhabbā ca mano ca dhammā ca.
analyzed: cakkhu ca iva rūpā ca sotañca saddā ca ghānañca gandhā ca jivhā ca rasā ca kāyo ca phoṭṭhabbā ca mano ca dhammā ca
translated: the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, the mind and thoughts.🔽When a monk knows and sees

original: Imāni kho, ānanda, cha ajjhattikabāhirāni āyatanāni yato jānāti passati—
analyzed: imāni kho ānanda cha ajjhattika bāhirāni āyatanāni yatas jānāti passati
translated: these six internal and external sense fields as they actually are,

original: ettāvatā kho, ānanda, ‘āyatanakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho ānanda āyatana kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: he is said to be a monk who is skilled in the sense fields.”

original: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, ‘paṭiccasamuppādakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā pana bhante paṭiccasamuppāda kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “But, Sir, in what way is a monk skilled in dependent origination?”

original: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu evam pajānāti
translated: “Here, Ānanda, a monk understands dependent origination as it really is.

original: ‘imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati,
analyzed: imasmin sati idam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati
translated: ‘When this exists, that comes to be; from the arising of this, that arises.

original: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhati, yadidaṁ—
analyzed: imasmin asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati
translated: When this doesn’t exist, that doesn’t come to be; from the cessation of this, that ceases. In other words:

original: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā,
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā
translated: With ignorance as condition, there are (volitional) processes.

original: saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṁ,🔽viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ,
analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇa  viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpa
translated: With (volitional) processes as condition, there is consciousness.🔽With consciousness as condition, there is mind and bodily form.

original: nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṁ,
analyzed: nāma rūpa paccayā
translated: With mind and bodily form as condition, there are the six sense spheres.

original: saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso,🔽phassapaccayā vedanā,
analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā phasso  phassa paccayā vedanā
translated: With the six sense spheres as condition, there is contact.🔽With contact as condition, there is feeling.

original: vedanāpaccayā taṇhā,🔽taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ,
analyzed: vedanā paccayā taṇhā  taṇhā paccayā upādāna
translated: With feeling as condition, there is craving.🔽With craving as condition, there is attachment.

original: upādānapaccayā bhavo,
analyzed: upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ
translated: With attachment as condition, there is continuation.

original: bhavapaccayā jāti,
analyzed: bhava paccayā jāti
translated: With continuation as condition, there is birth.

original: jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā sambhavanti.
analyzed: jāti paccayā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassu upāyāsā sambhavanti
translated: With birth as condition, there is old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise.

original: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.
analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti
translated: Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

original: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho,
analyzed: avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ
translated: But with the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance, there is the cessation of (volitional) processes.

original: saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho,🔽viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho,
analyzed: saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho  viññāṇa nirodhā nāma rūpa nirodho
translated: With the cessation of (volitional) processes, there is the cessation of consciousness.🔽With the cessation of consciousness, there is the cessation of mind and bodily form.

original: nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho,
analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhā saṃ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of mind and bodily form, there is the cessation of the six sense spheres.

original: saḷāyatananirodhā phassanirodho,
analyzed: saṅgāyatana nirodhā phassa nirodho
translated: With the cessation of the six sense spheres, there is the cessation of contact.

original: phassanirodhā vedanānirodho,
analyzed: phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho
translated: With the cessation of contact, there is the cessation of feeling.

original: vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho,
analyzed: vedanā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving.

original: taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho,🔽upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho,
analyzed: taṇhā nirodhāḥ upādāna nirodhaḥ  upādāna nirodhāḥ bhava nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging.🔽With the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of existence.

original: bhavanirodhā jātinirodho,
analyzed: bhava nirodhāḥ jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of existence comes the cessation of birth.

original: jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: jāti nirodhā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassu upāyāsāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: With the cessation of birth, aging-and-death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and distress all cease.

original: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti’.
analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti
translated: This is the cessation of the whole mass of suffering.

original: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, ‘paṭiccasamuppādakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho ānanda paṭiccasamuppāda kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: It is in this way that a monk is skilled in dependent origination.”

original: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, ‘ṭhānāṭhānakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā pana bhante ṭhāna aṭhāna kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: “But, Sir, in what way is a monk skilled in what is possible and what is impossible?”

original: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu ‘aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci saṅkhāraṁ niccato upagaccheyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yat diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalo kañci saṅkhāram niccatas upagaccheyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: “Here, Ananda, a monk understands: ‘It is impossible, it cannot happen that a person possessing right view could treat any formation as permanent,

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano kañci saṅkhāraṁ niccato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ kañci saṅkhāram niccatas upagaccheyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: but it is possible that an ordinary person might treat some formation as permanent.’

original: ‘aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci saṅkhāraṁ sukhato upagaccheyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ kañci saṅkhāram sukhataḥ upagaccheyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s impossible for a person who has right view to regard any phenomenon as being pleasant,

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano kañci saṅkhāraṁ sukhato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ kañci saṅkhāram sukhataḥ upagaccheyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: but it’s possible for an ordinary person to do so.’

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci dhammaṁ attato upagaccheyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti,🔽‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano kañci dhammaṁ attato upagaccheyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.🔽‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo mātaraṁ jīvitā voropeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalo kañci dhammaṃ attataḥ upagaccheyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti  ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ kañci dhammaṃ attataḥ upagaccheyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti  aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ mātaram jīvitā voropeyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s impossible for a person who has right view to regard any phenomenon as being self,🔽but it’s possible for an ordinary person to do so.’🔽‘It’s impossible for a person who has right view to kill their mother,

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano mātaraṁ jīvitā voropeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ mātaram jīvitā voropeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: but it’s possible for an ordinary person to do so.’

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo pitaraṁ jīvitā voropeyya …pe…🔽arahantaṁ jīvitā voropeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo duṭṭhacitto tathāgatassa lohitaṁ uppādeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ pitaram jīvitā voropeyya pe  arahantam jīvitā voropeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti  aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yat diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ duṭṭha cittaḥ tathāgatassa lohitam uppādeyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible, it cannot happen that a person who has right view could kill their mother …🔽kill their father …🔽kill an arahant …🔽It is impossible, it cannot happen that a person who has right view could, with a mind of hate, shed a Buddha’s blood …

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano duṭṭhacitto tathāgatassa lohitaṁ uppādeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yat puthujjanaḥ duṭṭha cittaḥ tathāgatassa lohitam uppādeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: It is possible that an ordinary person could, with a mind of hate, shed a Buddha’s blood.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo saṅghaṁ bhindeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano saṅghaṁ bhindeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ saṅgham bhindeyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti  ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ saṅgham bhindeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible, it cannot happen that a person who has right view could split the Sangha …🔽It is possible that an ordinary person could split the Sangha.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo aññaṁ satthāraṁ uddiseyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ aññam satthāram uddiseyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible, it cannot happen that a person who has right view could acknowledge another teacher …

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puthujjano aññaṁ satthāraṁ uddiseyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam puthujjanaḥ aññam satthāram uddiseyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s possible that an ordinary person might take another teacher,’ he knows that this is how it is.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjeyyuṁ, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yat ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahantaḥ sammāsambuddhāḥ apubbam acarimam uppajjeyyu na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s impossible for two Fully Enlightened Buddhas to arise in the one world-system without a trace of contradiction. There is no such possibility,’ he knows that this is how it is.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā eko arahaṁ sammāsambuddho uppajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.🔽‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve rājāno cakkavattino apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjeyyuṁ, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yat ekissā lokadhātuyā ekaḥ araham sammāsambuddhaḥ uppajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti  aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yat ekissā lokadhātuyā dve rājānaḥ cakkavattino apubbam acarimam uppajjeyyu na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s possible for one Fully Enlightened Buddha to arise in the one world-system,’ he knows that this is how it is.🔽‘It’s impossible for two Wheel-turning Monarchs to arise in the one world-system without a trace of contradiction. There is no such possibility,’ he knows that this is how it is.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā eko rājā cakkavattī uppajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yat ekissā lokadhātuyā ekaḥ rājā cakkavattī uppajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s possible for one Wheel-turning Monarch to arise in the one world-system,’ he knows that this is how it is.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ itthī arahaṁ assa sammāsambuddho, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam itthī arahan assa sammāsambuddhaḥ na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible for a woman to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha,’ he knows that this is so.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puriso arahaṁ assa sammāsambuddho, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam purisaḥ arahan assa sammāsambuddhaḥ ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is possible for a man to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha,’ he knows that this is so.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ itthī rājā assa cakkavattī, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam itthī rājā assa cakkavattī na etat ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible for a woman to be a king, a wheel-turning monarch,’ he knows that this is so.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puriso rājā assa cakkavattī, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.🔽‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ itthī sakkattaṁ kareyya … mārattaṁ kareyya … brahmattaṁ kareyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam purisaḥ rājā assa cakkavattī ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti  a ṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam itthī sakkattam kareyya mārattam kareyya brahmattam kareyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is possible for a man to be a king, a wheel-turning monarch,’ he knows that this is so.🔽‘It is impossible for a woman to be Śakra, lord of the gods,’ he knows that this is so.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ puriso sakkattaṁ kareyya … mārattaṁ kareyya … brahmattaṁ kareyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam purisaḥ sakkattam kareyya mārattam kareyya brahmattam kareyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is possible for a man to be Śakra, lord of the gods,’ he knows that this is so.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ kāyaduccaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam kāya duccaritassa iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya na etat ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s impossible for a bad action to result in a pleasant ripening. There’s no such possibility.’

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ kāyaduccaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yat kāya duccaritassa aniṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘But it’s possible for a bad action to result in an unpleasant ripening.’

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ vacīduccaritassa …pe…
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam vacīduccaritassa pe
translated: ‘It’s impossible for a bad verbal action …

original: yaṁ manoduccaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;🔽ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ vacīduccaritassa …pe…🔽yaṁ manoduccaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatīti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam manoduccaritassa iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti  ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam vacīduccaritassa pe  yam manoduccaritassa aniṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: for a bad mental action to result in a pleasant ripening. There’s no such possibility.’🔽‘But it’s possible for a bad mental action to result in an unpleasant ripening.’

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ kāyasucaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam kāya su caritassa aniṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya na etat ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s impossible for a good bodily action to result in an unpleasant ripening. There’s no such possibility.’

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ kāyasucaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.🔽‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ vacīsucaritassa …pe…🔽yaṁ manosucaritassa aniṭṭho akanto amanāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yat kāya su caritassa iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti  a ṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam vacīsu caritassa pe  yam manaḥ su caritassa aniṭṭhaḥ a kantaḥ a manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘But it is possible that the result of good bodily conduct might be pleasant experience,’ he understands it thus.

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ vacīsucaritassa …pe…
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam vacīsu caritassa pe
translated: ‘It is impossible and it cannot happen that one who has acted and made others act in a certain way can, with the breakup of the body, after death, be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world as a result of good verbal conduct …🔽as a result of good mental conduct,’ he understands it thus.

original: yaṁ manosucaritassa iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko nibbatteyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam manosu caritassa iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ vipākaḥ nibbatteyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘But it is possible that the result of good mental conduct might be pleasant experience,’ he understands it thus.

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam kāya duccarita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjeyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible and it cannot happen that one who has acted and made others act in a certain way can, with the breakup of the body, after death, be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world as a result of good bodily conduct,’ he understands it thus;

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam kāya duccarita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s possible that one who’s committed bodily misconduct …

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ vacīduccaritasamaṅgī …pe…🔽yaṁ manoduccaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ vacīduccaritasamaṅgī …pe…
analyzed: a ṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam  yam manaḥ duccarita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjeyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti  ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam vacīduccarita samaṅgī pe
translated: ‘It’s impossible that one who’s committed verbal misconduct …🔽‘It’s possible that one who’s committed mental misconduct …

original: yaṁ manoduccaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam manaḥ duccarita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It’s possible that one who’s committed bodily misconduct …

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ kāyasucaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam kāya su carita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjeyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is impossible for one who is endowed with bodily good conduct …🔽for one who is endowed with verbal good conduct …🔽for one who is endowed with mental good conduct, on the dissolution of the body, after death, to reappear in a state of deprivation, in an unhappy destination, in perdition, even in hell. Such a case is impossible.’

original: ‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ kāyasucaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam kāya su carita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: ‘It is possible for one who is endowed with bodily good conduct …

original: ‘Aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ vacīsucaritasamaṅgī …pe…
analyzed: a ṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam vacīsu carita samaṅgī
translated: for one who is endowed with verbal good conduct …

original: yaṁ manosucaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyya, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘ṭhānañca kho etaṁ vijjati yaṁ vacīsucaritasamaṅgī …pe…
analyzed: yam manaḥ su carita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjeyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti pajānāti 🔽ṭhānam ca kho etam vijjati yam vacīsu carita samaṅgī
translated: for one who is endowed with mental good conduct, on the dissolution of the body, after death, to reappear in a happy destination, even in the heavenly world. Such a case is possible.’

original: yaṁ manosucaritasamaṅgī taṁnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyya, ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam manaḥ su carita samaṅgī ta nidānā tad paccayā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjeyya ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti
translated: It is possible that one who has done what is good with the body, after the break-up of the body, after death, will be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.

original: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, ‘ṭhānāṭhānakusalo bhikkhū’ti alaṁvacanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho ānanda ṭhāna aṭhāna kusalaḥ bhikkhu iti alavacanāya ati
translated: To this extent, Ānanda, a monk is one who is skilled in the possible and the impossible.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Ven. Ānanda said to the Blessed One,

original: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: acchariya bhante abbhuta bhante
translated: “It’s amazing, lord. It’s astounding, how deep this dependent co-arising is, and how deep its appearance, and how the Tathāgata is so skilled in the way in, and so skilled in the way out, with regard to this dependent co-arising.

original: Konāmo ayaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
analyzed: konāmaḥ aya bhante dhammapariyāyo ti
translated: What is the name of this discourse on Dhamma?”🔽“In that case, Ānanda, you should repeat this discourse on Dhamma, calling it ‘The Many Kinds of Elements,’

original: “Tasmātiha tvaṁ, ānanda, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ ‘bahudhātuko’tipi naṁ dhārehi, ‘catuparivaṭṭo’tipi
analyzed: tasmāt iha tvam ānanda imam dhammapariyāyam bahu dhātukā utipi nam dhārehi catu parivaṭṭā utipi
translated: ‘The Fourfold Array,’🔽‘The Mirror of the Dhamma,’

original: naṁ dhārehi, ‘dhammādāso’tipi naṁ dhārehi, ‘amatadundubhī’tipi naṁ dhārehi, ‘anuttaro
analyzed: nam dhārehi dhammādāso tipi nam dhārehi amatadundubhi itipi nam dhārehi anuttaraḥ
translated: ‘The Drum of the Deathless,’

original: saṅgāmavijayo’tipi naṁ dhārehī”ti.
analyzed: nam dhārehi iti
translated: and ‘The Incomparable Victory in Battle.’”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti
translated: Pleased, Ven. Ānanda was satisfied in the Blessed One’s words.

original: Bahudhātukasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: bahu dhātuka suttam niṭṭhitam pañcama
translated: The Discourse on the Many Kinds of Elements is finished.
